1.title: Week 1: Intro to Microcontrollers
1.description: Hardware, inputs/outputs, MakeCode basics, events & sequencing.

questions.question: Which statement best describes the role of the microcontroller inside a micro:bit?
options: It processes sensor inputs and controls outputs according to your code
It only stores your program in memory
It powers the LEDs and buttons directly without processing
It connects the micro:bit to the internet
questions.explanation: The microcontroller is the 'brain' — it runs your program, reading inputs and sending signals to outputs.
questions.definition: MICROCONTROLLER — a small processor that executes code and manages inputs/outputs in embedded systems.
questions.hint: Think of it as the part that actually runs your code and decides what to do next.

questions.question: Which example shows the micro:bit receiving information from its surroundings?
options: Showing an arrow on the screen
Playing a sound through the speaker
Flashing the LEDs in a pattern
questions.explanation: The accelerometer senses movement — an input from the environment. The other options send information outward, making them outputs.
questions.hint: Ask yourself: is the micro:bit reading or displaying information?

questions.question: In the code below, which block ensures the text appears only one time before the heart starts flashing?
questions.code:
on start
  show string "Hello!"
forever
  show icon Heart
  pause(500)
  clear screen
  pause(500)
questions.explanation: Anything inside 'on start' runs just once. The 'forever' loop repeats endlessly, but 'on start' finishes after its commands.
questions.hint: Only one block type is designed for setup instructions that don’t repeat.

questions.question: If you upload this code to the micro:bit, what will you see happen and why?
questions.code:
forever
  show string "Hi"
options: It scrolls 'Hi' endlessly because there’s no stop condition
It only shows 'Hi' once because the display clears automatically
It shows 'Hi' five times, matching the number of LEDs
It waits for button A before showing 'Hi'
questions.explanation: Because the text is inside a 'forever' block, it repeats continuously without stopping until the micro:bit is reset or turned off.
questions.hint: Does anything in the code tell it to stop?

questions.question: The LED grid on a micro:bit can both show light and measure light levels. What type of device is it mostly considered?
options: Both input and output, but mainly output
questions.explanation: While the LED matrix can detect light levels, its primary role is to display information — so it’s mainly an output device.
questions.hint: It can sense light but that’s not its main purpose.

questions.question: Match each term to its definition.
questions.explanation: Event triggers code; sequence is order; debug means fix mistakes.
questions.hint: Cause → Event; order → Sequence; fixing → Debug.

questions.question: Where can you test your micro:bit program without using the real device?
options: In the MakeCode simulator on the screen
By opening the MICROBIT drive on your computer
By plugging in the battery pack only
questions.explanation: The MakeCode simulator runs your program virtually and lets you try buttons, shaking and LEDs on screen.
questions.definition: SIMULATOR — a virtual version of the micro:bit you can test inside MakeCode.
questions.hint: Which one shows a working virtual micro:bit on your screen?

questions.question: Which statement about 'on button A pressed' is true?
options: It runs in a loop automatically
It runs only when A is pressed
questions.explanation: Event code runs when the event happens — here, pressing Button A.
questions.hint: It waits for something to happen.

questions.question: What is a program?
options: A set of instructions a computer follows
An image on the LED matrix
questions.explanation: A program is a precise sequence of instructions.
questions.definition: PROGRAM — a precise list of instructions a computer follows.
questions.hint: Think of a recipe for a computer.

questions.question: Why might your program not appear on the micro:bit after download?
questions.explanation: All of these are common causes.
questions.hint: Check the obvious steps and connections.

questions.question: Which example shows input → process → output in the correct order?
questions.explanation: Input (button) → processing/logic → output (display).
questions.hint: First comes data in, then thinking, then feedback out.

questions.question: Which block would you use to run code continuously during the entire program?
questions.explanation: The forever loop keeps running as long as the program runs.
questions.hint: Think of a heartbeat the program always follows.

2.title: Week 2: Events & Random
2.description: Button events, dice rolling, randomness, simple probability.

questions.question: When does the code inside the block 'on button A pressed' actually run?
options: Only when button A is pressed down
questions.explanation: The code runs only when button A is pressed down. Other buttons or automatic timing don’t trigger it.
questions.hint: It listens for one exact action on one button.

questions.question: What does 'random 1 to 6' give you?
questions.explanation: It behaves like a fair six-sided die.
questions.definition: RANDOM — the computer chooses by chance from a range.
questions.hint: Think dice.

questions.question: What is an event in programming?
options: Something that triggers code to run
questions.explanation: Events trigger code when they occur (press, shake, start).
questions.hint: It’s the “when” that makes code start.

questions.question: This dice roller runs when you press Button A. What happens each time you press it?
questions.code:
on button A pressed
  set roll to random 1 to 6
  show number roll
options: It picks a new number from 1 to 6 and shows it
It keeps showing the same number every time
It adds 1 to the previous roll and shows that
It shows all six numbers quickly one after another
questions.explanation: Each button A press sets a new random value between 1 and 6, then displays that single number.
questions.hint: Think about what the 'random 1 to 6' block does on each button press.

questions.question: What is the chance of rolling a 4 on a fair six-sided die?
questions.explanation: Each face has equal probability: 1/6.
questions.hint: How many faces are there?

questions.question: If a die is rolled 60 times, about how many 3s would you expect?
questions.explanation: Expected frequency ≈ total × probability = 60 × 1/6 = 10.
questions.hint: Multiply the number of trials by the chance.

questions.question: Which block lets you react to movement of the micro:bit?
questions.explanation: The accelerometer triggers the shake event.
questions.hint: It’s tied to the accelerometer.

questions.question: Match the event to when it triggers.
questions.explanation: Each event maps to a different trigger; forever has no trigger.
questions.hint: Think: beginning, button, motion, always.

questions.question: What message might the micro:bit show when you press Button A?
questions.code:
on button A pressed
  set x to random 1 to 10
  if x > 5 then
    show string "Big"
  else
    show string "Small"
options: It shows 'Big' or 'Small' depending on the random number
It always shows 'Big' because 10 is the largest number
It shows 'Small' because x starts at 0
It shows both 'Big' and 'Small' one after another
questions.explanation: Each time you press A, a random number 1–10 is picked. If that number is greater than 5, 'Big' appears; otherwise 'Small'.
questions.hint: Remember: '>' means greater than.

questions.question: What is shown for this coin flip?
questions.code:
on button B pressed
  set flip to random 0 to 1
  if flip = 0 then
    show string "Heads"
  else
    show string "Tails"
questions.explanation: Random 0 to 1 maps perfectly to a fair coin.
questions.hint: Two possible values → two possible messages.

questions.question: When this code runs, you sometimes see two different numbers flash quickly. Why?
questions.code:
on button A pressed
  show number random 1 to 6
  show number random 1 to 6
options: Because each call to 'random 1 to 6' generates a new value right away
Because the same random value is shown twice at high speed
Because the micro:bit remembers the first number and repeats it
Because the button is pressed for too long
questions.explanation: Both lines use 'random 1 to 6', so two independent random numbers are shown in quick succession.
questions.hint: Does the code reuse the first random value or call it again?

questions.question: After pressing Button A five times, what number will the micro:bit show, and why?
questions.code:
on start
  set count to 0
on button A pressed
  change count by 1
  show number count
options: 5, because 'count' increases by 1 each time and keeps its value
1, because 'count' resets to 0 on every press
0, because the program only runs 'on start'
questions.explanation: The variable 'count' keeps increasing — 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 — with each press.
questions.hint: Does 'set count to 0' happen each time you press the button?

questions.question: What does the else part of an if–else do?
options: Runs when the if is true
Runs when the if is false
questions.explanation: Else handles the “otherwise” case when the if condition isn’t met.
questions.hint: Think: backup plan.

questions.question: Look at this code. Which symbol is checking if the score is exactly 10?
questions.code:
if score = 10 then
  show string "Winner!"
questions.explanation: The '=' sign checks equality.
questions.hint: It compares, not adds.

questions.question: The micro:bit picks a random number 1 to 3 to play Rock–Paper–Scissors. What must the code do next to decide who wins?
options: Use if–else blocks to compare your choice and the random pick
Use 'show string' to display all three options at once
Add 3 to the random number to get the winner
Wait 1 second before showing a smiley
questions.explanation: After choosing randomly, the program compares both choices using if–else logic.
questions.hint: How does the program decide which move wins?

questions.question: What message appears for x = 7?
questions.code:
on button A pressed
  set x to 7
  if x > 5 then
    show string "Big"
  else
    show string "Small"
questions.explanation: 7 > 5 is true, so it shows “Big”.
questions.hint: Is 7 greater than 5?

questions.question: What’s the output if number = 5?
questions.code:
set number to 5
if number < 5 then
  show string "Low"
else if number = 5 then
  show string "Equal"
else
  show string "High"
questions.explanation: The second condition matches exactly.
questions.hint: Check the exact equality branch.

questions.question: If a coin is fair, what’s the chance of Heads?
questions.explanation: A fair coin has two equally likely outcomes.
questions.hint: How many equally likely outcomes are there?

questions.question: Which condition correctly checks for a tie?
questions.code:
set player to "Rock"
set computer to "Rock"
if ???? then
  show string "Tie!"
questions.explanation: A tie occurs when both choices are equal.
questions.hint: Same on both sides.

questions.question: Match the comparison to an example that makes it true.
questions.explanation: Each example satisfies the comparison shown.
questions.hint: Plug in the numbers mentally.

questions.question: What does it show when A is pressed?
questions.code:
on button A pressed
  set roll to random 1 to 6
  if roll = 6 then
    show icon "trophy"
  else
    show number roll
questions.explanation: It branches on a special case: a roll of 6.
questions.hint: Which value triggers the special icon?

questions.question: What will the display show?
questions.code:
set a to 3
set b to 7
if a > b then
  show string "A"
else if a = b then
  show string "Equal"
else
  show string "B"
questions.explanation: 3 > 7 is false; 3 = 7 is false; it falls through to “B”.
questions.hint: Compare 3 and 7 in order.

questions.question: Why can’t this ever show "B"?
questions.code:
set n to 90
if n >= 90 then
  show string "A"
else if n >= 90 then
  show string "B"
else
  show string "C"
options: Because the second condition repeats the first
questions.explanation: The second branch is unreachable since it duplicates the first condition.
questions.hint: Look for a repeated test.

questions.question: What message appears when the code runs?
questions.code:
set temp to 20
set light to 30
if temp >= 18 and light >= 50 then
  show string "Go Outside"
else
  show string "Stay In"
questions.explanation: Both conditions must be true; light is too low.
questions.hint: and means both must pass.

4.title: Week 4: Variables & Thresholds
4.description: Storing values, comparing to limits, using sensors (light & temperature).

questions.question: What is a variable used for in MakeCode?
options: To store a value that can change while the program runs
To repeat blocks over and over
To read values from sensors like light or temperature
To play sounds or show icons
questions.explanation: A variable is a named space in memory where the program keeps a value that can change, such as a score or sensor reading.
questions.hint: It’s like a labelled box you can open and replace what’s inside.

questions.question: What does 'change score by 5' do if score was 10?
questions.explanation: It adds 5 to the current value: 10 + 5 = 15.
questions.hint: This operation adds, it doesn’t replace.

questions.question: In a micro:bit program, what does a threshold represent?
options: A limit value that decides when something should happen
The exact sensor reading at the start of the program
A random number between two limits
The highest possible temperature the micro:bit can read
questions.explanation: A threshold is a boundary value used to trigger an action — for example, if light level < 100, turn on a torch.
questions.hint: It’s the line between 'go' and 'stop' conditions.

questions.question: If the classroom light level is 80, what message appears when this code runs?
questions.code:
set lightLevel to light level
if lightLevel < 50 then
  show string "Too Dark!"
else
  show string "OK"
questions.explanation: The condition is false when lightLevel = 80, so it shows 'OK'.
questions.hint: Which branch runs when the condition is false?

questions.question: What is health after running?
questions.code:
set health to 100
change health by -20
set health to health * 2
questions.hint: Apply steps in order.

questions.question: Match each variable operation to its effect.
questions.explanation: “set” replaces the value; “change by” adds/subtracts.
questions.hint: Replace vs. add.

questions.question: What will display when temp = 35?
questions.code:
set temp to temperature (onboard sensor)
set threshold to 30
if temp > threshold then
  show string "Too Hot!"
else
  show string "OK"
questions.explanation: 35 > 30 is true, so it shows 'Too Hot!'.
questions.hint: Compare the numbers directly.

questions.question: Which code correctly stores the current light sensor reading into a variable?
questions.explanation: The command stores the live sensor reading into the variable.
questions.hint: Only one uses the actual light sensor reading.

questions.question: Where does the temperature value come from in micro:bit projects?
questions.explanation: We use the micro:bit’s onboard sensor.
questions.hint: No extra hardware this week.

questions.question: You want your plant monitor to warn only when it’s cold and dark. Which line should fill the blank?
questions.code:
set temp to temperature (onboard)
set light to light level (onboard)
if __________ then
  show string "Cold & Dark"
questions.explanation: and requires both conditions to be true.
questions.hint: Which condition checks that both sensors are below their limits?

questions.question: What’s the logic mistake?
questions.code:
set temp to temperature
if temp > 30 and temp > 40 then
  show string "Hot!"
else
  show string "OK"
options: The first comparison is redundant; effectively temp > 40
questions.explanation: If both conditions are '>', the larger threshold dominates.
questions.hint: Which comparison is stricter?

questions.question: What does the code display?
questions.code:
set points to 10
change points by 15
set points to points * 2
show number points
questions.hint: Follow each step carefully.

5.title: Week 5: Loops & First Game
5.description: repeat/for/while/forever loops; timing (millis); sprites and simple game logic.

questions.question: What does a FOREVER loop do?
options: Runs a fixed number of times
questions.explanation: It repeats as long as the program is active.
questions.hint: Think: the main heartbeat of a game.

questions.question: What does 'repeat 3 times' do?
options: Runs until a condition is met
questions.explanation: It iterates a fixed number of times.
questions.hint: Count the passes.

questions.question: What is an ITERATION?
questions.explanation: Each cycle of a loop is an iteration.
questions.hint: Imagine stepping through a dance routine once.

questions.question: What will this code make the micro:bit do?
questions.code:
forever
  repeat 5 times
    show icon "heart"
    pause 200
    show icon "small heart"
    pause 200
  clear screen
  pause 800
options: Show one heart that never changes
Show five heartbeats, then pause briefly, repeating forever
Show a random sequence of icons
Show five hearts once and then stop
questions.explanation: The inner 'repeat 5' loop creates five quick heartbeats; the outer 'forever' repeats the pattern.
questions.hint: Think about how the inner loop runs inside the forever loop.

questions.question: What numbers will be shown?
questions.code:
set counter to 1
repeat 5 times
  show number counter
  change counter by 1
  pause 500
questions.explanation: It starts at 1 and increments after each display.
questions.hint: Check the starting value.

questions.question: What does using 'millis' (elapsed ms) help with?
options: Measuring time between actions for smooth speed control
questions.explanation: millis/elapsed time lets you time updates precisely (e.g., speed).
questions.hint: Think: timers and intervals.

questions.question: What movement happens on the LED screen?
questions.code:
set sprite to create sprite at x 0 y 2
repeat 4 times
  change sprite x by 1
  pause 150
questions.explanation: Changing x by +1 four times moves it 4 columns to the right.
questions.hint: Positive x goes right; negative x goes left.

questions.question: Match each loop type to what it does in a program.
definitions: Repeats as long as a test remains true
Keeps running endlessly while the program is active
Steps through numbers in order, useful for counting or indexing
Repeats a specific number of times, then stops
questions.explanation: ‘forever’ never ends; ‘repeat N times’ stops after a set count; ‘while’ repeats while a test stays true; ‘for index’ steps through a counting range.
questions.hint: Think: condition / endless / counting / fixed.

questions.question: How many times will it run?
questions.code:
set c to 10
while c > 5
  show number c
  change c by -2
questions.explanation: c takes values 10, 8, 6 then stops (3 passes).
questions.hint: Track c step by step.

questions.question: This loop is part of a game timer. What happens when the code runs?
questions.code:
set counter to 9
while counter > 0
    if counter < 0 then
        change counter by -1
    pause 100
questions.explanation: The if never runs (condition counter < 0 is never true), so counter never changes; loop never ends.
questions.hint: Does the if condition ever become true?

questions.question: What is printed at the end?
questions.code:
set s to 0
for i from 1 to 4
  change s by i
show number s
questions.hint: Add the range 1..4.

questions.question: What pattern of beeps will you hear?
questions.code:
set wait to 600
repeat 3 times
  play tone C
  pause wait
  change wait by -200
questions.explanation: The pause shrinks each iteration, so beeps come quicker.
questions.hint: Watch the pause value change.

6.title: Week 6: Core Mechanics — Loops, Logic, Timing & Coordinates
6.description: Reusable challenge set mixing loops, variables, timing, coordinates, and debugging.

questions.question: A loop updates a sprite once per iteration and then pauses for 80 ms. Approximately how many updates happen in 2 seconds?
questions.explanation: 2,000 ms / 80 ms ≈ 25 iterations (rounding down).
questions.hint: Convert seconds to milliseconds first.

questions.question: A sprite starts at x = 2 on the bottom row of the LED grid. The code runs three times. Where will the sprite end up?
questions.code:
set x = 2
repeat 3 times
  if x > 0 then change x by -1
end
options: One step left of the start position
questions.explanation: Each loop step moves the sprite one space left while x > 0. After two moves it reaches x = 0, and the last if does nothing because x is no longer greater than 0.
questions.hint: Imagine the sprite moving left one step each loop until it reaches the edge.

questions.question: A program increments the score when an event occurs. It begins with score = 3 and speed = 200 ms. The event happens 7 times; each time the score increments by 1 and the speed decreases by 10. What are the final values?
questions.explanation: Increment means increase — here the score increases by 1 each time (3 + 7 = 10). The speed decreases by 10 each time (200 − 70 = 130 ms).
questions.hint: Increment means 'increase by' — think about how both values change each event.

questions.question: Look at this game loop. What happens when the sprite touches an obstacle?
questions.code:
forever
  move sprite by 1
  if sprite is touching obstacle then
    game over
  show number score
options: The score shows one more time after game over
The game stops immediately after game over, so anything after that line doesn’t run
The loop restarts from the top after game over
questions.explanation: In MakeCode, 'game over' ends the program. Any code after it — even in the same loop — will not run.
questions.hint: When the game ends, does the micro:bit still keep running the forever loop?

questions.question: A micro:bit should play an alarm only if it’s dark and Button A is pressed. When will the sound play?
questions.code:
if light < 50 and button A is pressed then
    play sound 'alarm'
else
    stop all sounds
options: Only when it’s dark and Button A is pressed
Whenever it’s dark, even if Button A isn’t pressed
Whenever Button A is pressed, no matter the light
It never plays because the light test comes first
questions.explanation: Both conditions must be true at the same time — dark and button pressed — for the alarm to play. The 'and' block joins two tests together.
questions.hint: Both parts of the 'and' must be true together.

questions.question: What is the value of c after the loop finishes?
questions.code:
set c = 1
repeat 5 times
  change c by 2
end
questions.explanation: c increases by 2 five times: 1 + 10 = 11.
questions.hint: Repeated addition.

questions.question: About how many times does count increase during ~1 second of running?
questions.code:
set count = 0
set start = millis()
while millis() < start + 1000
  change count by 1
  pause (50)
end
questions.explanation: ≈ 1000/50 = 20 increments (ignoring small overheads).
questions.hint: Divide total time by pause time.

questions.question: How many times does 'plot' run on a 5×5 LED grid?
questions.code:
for x from 0 to 4
  for y from 0 to 4
    plot (x, y)
  end
end
questions.explanation: 5×5 = 25 total iterations.
questions.hint: Multiply the sizes of both ranges.

questions.question: After the loop, what are x and dir?
questions.code:
set x = 2
set dir = +1
repeat 6 times
  if x = 4 then set dir = -1
  if x = 0 then set dir = +1
  change x by dir
end
questions.explanation: Trace: 2→3→4 (flip next)→3→2→1→0; after 6 steps, x = 0 and dir is -1 (flip would occur next).
questions.hint: Check when dir flips: before or after moving?

questions.question: Why does the score remain 0?
questions.code:
set score = 0
forever
  if event then change score by 1
  set score = 0
end
options: The score is reset to 0 every loop iteration
Variables cannot be changed inside forever
The change block only works once
questions.explanation: The reset happens on every pass, wiping any increment.
questions.hint: Look at where 'set score = 0' is placed.

questions.question: A sprite starts at x = 1 on the bottom row of the micro:bit screen. The code below runs twice. Where does the sprite end up?
questions.code:
set x = 1
repeat 2 times
  if x < 3 then change x by 2 else change x by -1
end
questions.explanation: First loop: 1 < 3 so x becomes 3. Second loop: 3 < 3 is false, so x changes by −1 and becomes 2. Final x = 2.
questions.hint: Follow each step: check the condition, then change x accordingly.

questions.question: A sprite moves across the screen in a forever loop. Where should the 'change score by 1' block go if you want the score to increase every time the sprite reaches the edge?
options: Inside the loop, after checking if sprite is touching the edge
At the very top of the loop, before any checks
Outside the loop, after the forever block
Anywhere in the code — it doesn’t matter
questions.explanation: You need to check the edge first, then increase the score inside the loop when that condition is true. Code outside the loop only runs once at the start.
questions.hint: Forever loops repeat actions — things outside them happen only once.

7.title: Week 7: Functions, Variables, Loops, Conditions & Sensors
7.description: Upper-KS2 quiz mixing functions as reusable helpers, accelerometer reasoning, loop/timing maths, and clear pseudocode tracing. Balanced difficulty.

questions.question: Why do programmers use functions when making games?
options: To store numbers like score or speed
To reuse the same set of steps without rebuilding them each time
To keep the game running forever
questions.explanation: Functions let you reuse the same instructions instead of repeating code, which makes games easier to change later.
questions.definition: FUNCTION — a named mini-program that does one clear job; you call it when you need it.
questions.hint: Think: reuse the same instructions instead of repeating them.

questions.question: What number is shown at the end?
questions.code:
function bumpLevel()
    change level by 1
end function

set level to 2
repeat 2 times
    call bumpLevel()
end
show number level
questions.explanation: level: 2 → 3 → 4, then displayed.
questions.hint: The helper runs twice.

questions.question: A sprite moves left or right based on tilt. Starting at x = 2, after readings 350, 100, −260, what is x? (Move right if X > +200; left if X < −200; otherwise no move.)
questions.code:
set x to 2
repeat 3 times
    if acceleration (X) > 200 then
        change x by 1
    else if acceleration (X) < -200 then
        change x by -1
    end if
end
show number x
questions.hint: Only big tilts (>|200|) move the sprite.

questions.question: Which branch runs for a right tilt (X = +400)?
questions.code:
if acceleration (X) > 200 then
    move sprite right
else if acceleration (X) < -200 then
    move sprite left
end if
questions.explanation: Positive X over the threshold triggers the first branch.
questions.hint: Positive = right.

questions.question: In a game, speed (ms) gets smaller by 20 each score but can’t go below 80 ms. Starting at 180 ms, what is speed after 6 scores?
questions.code:
set speed to 180
repeat 6 times
    change speed by -20
    if speed < 80 then
        set speed to 80
    end if
end
show number speed
questions.hint: Stop at the minimum.

questions.question: The level is worked out as: level = 1 + (score ÷ 4) using whole-number division. What is the smallest score that gives level = 3?
questions.code:
set level to 1
# level = 1 + (score ÷ 4)   # ÷ means integer division (floor)
# Choose the smallest score that makes level become 3
questions.explanation: At score 8: 8 ÷ 4 = 2, so level = 1 + 2 = 3. At 7 it’s still 2.
questions.hint: Divide by 4 (no decimals), then add 1.

questions.question: What number is shown at the end?
questions.code:
set score to 0
function addPoint()
    change score by 1
end function

repeat 3 times
    call addPoint()
end
show number score
questions.explanation: addPoint runs three times → score = 3.
questions.hint: Count the calls.

questions.question: Total pause time (ms) for the whole program?
questions.code:
function blink(times, ms)
    repeat times times
        show icon "heart"
        pause ms
        clear screen
        pause ms
    end repeat
end function

repeat 3 times
    call blink(2, 150)
end
questions.explanation: One call: 2 × (150+150) = 600 ms. Three calls → 1800 ms.
questions.hint: Each blink cycle has two pauses.

questions.question: What message appears on the screen?
questions.code:
set temp to 18
if temp > 30 then
    show string "Hot"
else if temp < 18 then
    show string "Cold"
else
    show string "OK"
end if
questions.explanation: At exactly 18, neither >30 nor <18 is true → “OK”.
questions.hint: Mind the strict > and <.

questions.question: Which block fits the blank so this runs three times after A is pressed (and not forever)?
questions.code:
on button A pressed
    ______
        move sprite by 1
        pause 150
    end
questions.explanation: “repeat 3 times” limits it to three moves per press.
questions.hint: Look for a fixed-count loop.

questions.question: Starting at x = 1, the sprite moves when the tilt is big. Readings: 250, 250, −300. Rule: if X > +200 move right (+1); if X < −200 move left (−1); otherwise no move. What number is shown?
questions.code:
set x to 1
for each reading in [250, 250, -300]

questions.question: Why set isShowing to true while a level message is on screen?
questions.code:
set isShowing to false

function showLevel(level)
    set isShowing to true
    show string "L"
    show number level
    pause 300
    set isShowing to false
end function

forever
    if isShowing then
        pause 10
    else
        update game world
    end if
options: To speed up the game loop
To pause game updates so movement doesn’t happen during the message
questions.explanation: The flag makes the main loop idle so players can read the message without the game moving.
questions.hint: It’s a simple on/off switch for the main loop.
